summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from Bulletin Intelligence dated December 8, 2020. It is a daily compilation of news headlines and summaries covering a wide range of topics including leading news, protests, counter-terrorism, counter-intelligence, criminal investigations, and other FBI-related news. The document includes a brief mention of Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys seeking bail, but is otherwise a general news digest not focused on the Epstein case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in a brief news item stating her attorneys are seeking her release on bail, noting she has lost weight and hair under jail conditions.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who claimed her client suffers under onerous jail conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case, who will decide whether to conduct a bail hearing.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the onetime boyfriend of Ghislaine Maxwell, whose suicide in federal custody was cited as a reason for her strict jail conditions.

connections.description: Described as the onetime girlfriend of Jeffrey Epstein.
Bobbi Sternheim is a defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Attorneys Seek Bail for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys renewed her application for release on bail, claiming she suffers under onerous jail conditions imposed partly due to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide.

keyFacts: The document is primarily a general FBI/news briefing covering a vast array of topics from December 8, 2020, with only a single, brief item related to the Epstein case.
The Epstein-related item reports that Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys are seeking her release on bail, citing her declining health in jail.
The jail conditions for Maxwell are described as being strict, partly because Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in federal custody the previous year.
Judge Alison J. Nathan is noted as the judge who will decide on holding a bail hearing later in December 2020.
The overwhelming majority of the document's content is unrelated to Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, or associated investigations.
